choices.text: Suction and evacuation, send to histopathological examination
Dilation and curettage (D&C), send to histopathological examination
Obstetrical Hysterectomy, send to histopathological examination
Inj tranexamic acid and serial beta HCG

questions.text: A 30 years female, Gravida 1 Para 0 presented with 10 weeks amenorrhea, breast tenderness, and nausea. However, she reports excessive vaginal bleeding and passage of clusters of tissue. There is no fetal movement or heartbeat detected. Ultrasound image is given. What would be the next step?
questions.solution:
A complete mole is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease resulting from abnormal fertilization, leading to the formation of a mass of abnormal tissue in the uterus. Key features include:

Clinical Presentation:

  • Amenorrhea, breast tenderness, and nausea.
  • Excessive vaginal bleeding and passage of grape-like clusters of tissue.
  • No fetal movement or heartbeat detected.

Diagnostic Findings:

  • Ultrasound reveals a characteristic "snowstorm" appearance.
  • Extremely elevated beta-hCG levels.

Histopathology confirms hydropic villi with an absence of fetal tissue.

Immunohistochemistry: Beta-hCG and p57 markers may be used for confirmation.

Molecular Studies: DNA ploidy analysis for further genetic characterization.

Treatment:

  • Evacuation of the uterus through dilation and curettage (D&C).
  • Regular monitoring of beta-hCG levels to ensure normalization.

Follow-up:

  • Contraception advised to prevent subsequent pregnancy.
  • Long-term follow-up to monitor for gestational trophoblastic neoplasia.

A D&C not only provides diagnostic confirmation but also serves as a therapeutic measure by removing the abnormal trophoblastic tissue. Close follow-up is crucial for a successful outcome.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 1178-79

choices.text: Cavity formation due to pulmonary tuberculosis

questions.text: A 11 months old Sarah is brought to the emergency room by her parents due to the sudden onset of symptoms over the past 48 hours. They report that she has had a high fever (up to 103°F or 39.4°C), rapid breathing, and a persistent cough. Sarah also complains of chest pain, and her parents have noticed her becoming increasingly fatigued and irritable. On Lung Examination Crackles over the affected lung area is noted. Chest Xray shown below. What could be the most likely diagnosis for immediate management?
questions.solution:
The Given CXR shows thin-walled cystic spaces within the lung parenchyma, containing air Called as Pneumatoceles. They are most commonly due to Staph. Aureus Infection usually in infants.

A) Cystic fibrosis presented with pneumonia:

Here's a concise comparison of the radiological findings between cystic fibrosis and lobar pneumonia:

C)

Here's a concise comparison of the clinical presentation and radiological features between pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) and lobar pneumonia:

D) Here's a concise comparison between laryngotracheitis (croup) and lobar pneumonia:

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number:246-48

choices.text: Periodic follow up with CT thorax
CT guided biopsy and histopathological examination

questions.text: A 54 years old male, Mr. Smit works in IT Office presents to the clinic with no specific complaints but is concerned about a recent finding on a routine chest X-ray and undergoes CT thorax. He has no significant medical history, non-smoker. Here is the one of the image of CT scan. What would be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Given CT Imaging Appearance suggest Well-defined, rounded nodule with central fat attenuation with characteristic "Popcorn" or "ball of wool" calcification pattern.

Surrounding Lung Tissue shows no signs of infiltration.

Findings are in favour of pulmonary hamartoma.

Management:

Observation: Often asymptomatic; no intervention needed if the lesion is stable and patient is asymptomatic.

Follow-up Imaging: Periodic imaging to monitor stability.

Biopsy (Optional): Considered if diagnosis is uncertain or if there is suspicion of malignancy.

Surgical Excision (Rarely): Reserved for symptomatic cases, rapid growth, or diagnostic uncertainty

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 181-82

choices.text: Give Oxygen, IV antibiotics and repeat Chest Xray 48 hours to look for residual infection
Advice D-dimer, CTPA and venous doppler
Advice Sputum AFB and CB-NAAT to confirm pulmonary tuberculosis

questions.text: Mrs. Ambani, 55 years old female, presents with sudden dyspnoea, chest pain, and cough. Known case of Ca Cervix. Exam reveals tachycardia, decreased breath sounds on right, and right calf tenderness. Chest X-ray shown below. What would be the next step?
questions.solution:
• Chest X-ray shows hamptons hump, and
  • CTPA confirms a large pulmonary embolism.
  • D-dimer for screening, Oxygen, anticoagulation, and pain management initiated.
  • Follow-up imaging and DVT evaluation by venous doppler planned.

While pulmonary embolism (PE) is primarily diagnosed through imaging modalities such as CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA), certain findings on chest X-rays may suggest the presence of PE indirectly. It's important to note that chest X-rays alone are not sufficient for a definitive diagnosis of PE, but they can provide supportive evidence and help rule out other conditions. Common X-ray signs associated with pulmonary embolism include:

Described chest radiographic signs include:

  1. Fleischner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery
  2. Hampton hump: peripheral wedge of airspace opacity and implies lung infarction
  3. Westermark sign: regional oligemia and highest positive predictive value
  4. Pleural effusion (most commmon) - pleural effusions in pulmonary embolism
  5. knuckle sign
  6. Palla sign: enlarged right descending pulmonary artery
  7. Chang sign: dilated right descending pulmonary artery with sudden cut-off

Hampton hump

Fleischner sign

The Wells Score is a clinical tool used to assess the pretest probability of pulmonary embolism (PE). Here are the criteria and the corresponding scores:

  • Clinical signs and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) - 3 points
  • An alternative diagnosis is less likely than PE - 3 points
  • Heart rate above 100 beats per minute - 1.5 points
  • Immobilization or surgery within the last 4 weeks - 1.5 points
  • Previous DVT or PE - 1.5 points
  • Hemoptysis - 1 point
  • Malignancy (with treatment within the last 6 months or palliative) - 1 point

Interpretation of Wells Score:

  • Low Probability (Wells Score < 2): PE is unlikely.
  • Intermediate Probability (Wells Score 2 - 6): Further testing, such as D-dimer and imaging, may be considered.
  • High Probability (Wells Score > 6): PE is likely, and imaging for confirmation is usually recommended.

It's important to note that the Wells Score is a clinical prediction rule, and the decision to pursue further diagnostic testing, such as imaging (CTPA)

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 246-48

choices.text: Characteristic imaging pattern shows small, rounded opacities, typically upper zones.
Risk of mesothelioma is more than bronchogenic carcinoma
Almost always involve parietal pleura-particularly the involvement of the diaphragmatic dome is more specific.
It typically causes cavitation in the lungs.

questions.text: A 65-year-old former shipyard worker, presents with gradual shortness of breath, persistent cough, and chest discomfort. Physical exam shows cyanosis, bibasilar crackles, and clubbing. Diagnostic tests. Chest Xray shown below. Which the following statement is true about the condition?
questions.solution:
• Chest radiograph shows irregular opacities with a fine reticular pattern. Additional evidence of asbestos exposure such as calcified or noncalcified pleural plaques may be evident.
    Pleural effusionsand pleural plaques are common manifestations of asbestos-related disease.
  • Above findings are in favour of diagnosis Asbestos-related diseases-
  • Asbestos-related disease, in particular affecting the lung, comprise of a broad spectrum of entities related to the inhalational exposure to asbestos fibers.

Asbestos-related benign pleural and parenchymal disease

  • Benign asbestos-induced pleural effusions: benign exudative
  • pleural plaques-almost always involve parietal pleura-particularly the involvement of the diaphragmatic dome is more specific for asbestos-related disease
  • round atelectasis (asbestos pseudotumor: Blesovsky syndrome)
  • asbestosis: progressive pulmonary interstitial fibrosis

Malignant

bronchogenic carcinoma

mesothelioma: less common than bronchogenic carcinoma but has a higher prevalence of asbestos exposure-pleural mesothelioma (option B )

extrapleural (e.g. peritoneal) mesothelioma

renal cell carcinoma

laryngeal carcinoma

gastrointestinal tumors

While asbestosis is characterized by certain radiological and clinical features, there are several characteristics not typical of this condition. It's important to note that individual cases can vary, and the absence of these features does not rule out asbestosis completely. Here are some features not typically associated with asbestosis:

Cavitation: Asbestosis typically does not cause cavitation in the lungs. The presence of cavities is more suggestive of conditions like infections or certain types of lung cancers. (option D)

Upper Lung Zone Predominance: Asbestosis typically affects the lower lung zones, especially the subpleural areas. If lung disease predominantly involves the upper lung zones, other conditions such as silicosis or sarcoidosis may be considered.

Nodules with a Progressive Massive Fibrosis Pattern: Large, conglomerate masses of fibrosis, known as progressive massive fibrosis (PMF), are more characteristic of coal worker's pneumoconiosis (black lung disease) rather than asbestosis.

Granulomas: Asbestosis is not associated with the formation of granulomas, which are a hallmark feature of diseases like sarcoidosis.

Eosinophilic Pneumonia: The presence of eosinophilic pneumonia, characterized by an increased number of eosinophils in the lungs, is not a typical feature of asbestosis.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 357-58

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presented with severe pain abdomen since 1 hour. He recently had a radius fracture for which he's been taking lot of painkillers. CXR is shown here. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
The presence of air under the diaphragm is a radiological finding that can be observed on imaging studies such as X-rays or computed tomography (CT) scans. This phenomenon is often referred to as "free air" or "pneumoperitoneum".

Here are some key points regarding the presence of air under the diaphragm:

  1. Normal Anatomy:
    • In normal circumstances, the abdominal organs are contained within the peritoneal cavity, and there is no air in this space.
  2. Causes of Air under Diaphragm:
    • The presence of air under the diaphragm is abnormal and may be indicative of various medical conditions, such as:
      • Perforated Hollow Viscus: Perforation or rupture of a hollow organ in the abdomen, such as the stomach or intestines, can lead to the escape of air into the peritoneal cavity.
      • Abdominal Trauma: Injuries to the abdomen that cause rupture or perforation of organs can result in pneumoperitoneum.
      • Post-Surgical Complications: Surgical procedures involving the abdominal cavity may lead to the unintentional introduction of air.
      • Gastrointestinal Disorders: Some gastrointestinal conditions, such as bowel obstruction, can lead to the accumulation of air.
    • In given scenario,
      • History of patient taking multiple pain killers with air under diaphragm points towards gastric perforation which needs urgent exploratory laparotomy.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 596-597

choices.text: Initial resuscitation includes intravenous fluids, and attempts are made to decompress the bowel using a rectal tube or sigmoidoscope.
It is a gastrointestinal emergency, and surgical intervention, such as endoscopic detorsion or resection, may be necessary if non-operative measures fail.
Primary provisional diagnosis of cecal volvulus is made.
Erect abdominal X-ray reveals the classic "coffee bean" or "omega" sign.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of severe abdominal pain, bloating, and constipation. The patient, with a history of chronic constipation, exhibits abdominal distention and tenderness, and an abdominal X-ray shows below.

Which of the following is not true about the condition?
questions.solution:
• The radiological findings of sigmoid volvulus can be characteristic and aid in the diagnosis of this condition. Imaging studies, particularly abdominal X-rays, play a crucial role in identifying the signs of sigmoid volvulus. Here are the key radiological features associated with sigmoid volvulus:

Coffee Bean Sign or Omega Sign:

  • The classic radiological sign of sigmoid volvulus is often referred to as the "coffee bean" sign or "omega" sign.
  • It appears on an abdominal X-ray and results from the twisting or torsion of the sigmoid colon, creating a characteristic double-loop appearance resembling a coffee bean or the Greek letter omega.

Loop in Lower Abdomen:

  • The twisted sigmoid loop is typically located in the lower abdomen, and its distinctive shape is evident on the X-ray.

Distended Bowel Segments:

  • The affected sigmoid colon appears dilated and distended proximal to the point of torsion due to the obstruction of normal fecal flow.

Absence of Gas in the Rectum:

  • The presence of the obstruction often leads to a lack of gas in the rectum, which can be observed on X-ray.

Management:

  • Emergent Resuscitation: Intravenous fluids and correction of electrolyte imbalances.
  • Decompression: Initial attempts at decompression with a rectal tube or a sigmoidoscope to relieve the colonic distention.
  • General surgery: May include endoscopic detorsion or surgical intervention (sigmoid resection) if non-operative measures fail.
  • Monitoring: Close monitoring of vital signs and abdominal examination for signs of peritonitis or worsening obstruction.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 566-567

choices.text: Barium swallow reveals class rat tail appearance,
Diagnosis to be considered is Achalasia cardia
Next investigation to be considered is oesophageal manometry
Pneumatic dilation or laparoscopic Heller myotomy are considered as treatment options

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female presents with a history of progressive dysphagia for solids and liquids over several months. She describes regurgitation of undigested food and occasional chest pain. Barium swallow reveals as shown below.

Which of the following is not true about condition?
questions.solution:
• Barium swallow reveals a classic "bird beak" appearance at the gastroesophageal junction, indicative of achalasia cardia.
  • Esophageal manometry confirms impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation and absent peristalsis in the esophageal body, consistent with a diagnosis of achalasia.
  • The patient undergoes further evaluation ruling out secondary causes of dysmotility. Endoscopic assessment excludes mucosal lesions. Given the symptomatic nature and diagnostic findings, pneumatic dilation or laparoscopic Heller myotomy are considered as treatment options
  1. Bird beak - achalasia cardia
  2. Rat tail appearance - esophageal malignancy of malignant stricture

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 614-617

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with abnormal uterine bleeding. USG is shown here. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Endometrial Polyps-

On transvaginal ultrasound, endometrial polyps appear as well-defined, echogenic masses within the uterine cavity.

They are often characterized by a hyperechoic central area, indicative of fibrous tissue or blood vessels.

Doppler ultrasound can reveal a specific vascular pattern, with peripheral blood vessels supplying the polyp.

The presence of endometrial polyps is associated with symptoms like abnormal uterine bleeding or postmenopausal bleeding.

While ultrasonography is valuable for detection and initial characterization, definitive diagnosis and treatment are typically accomplished through hysteroscopy, allowing direct visualization and removal of the polyp.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol II, Page number. 1024-25

questions.text: A 13-year-old male patient presenting with epistaxis underwent CECT. What is the sign demonstrated in the given image?
questions.solution:
The Holman-Miller Sign (also called the antral sign)

  • Seen in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma; it refers to the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary antrum as seen on CECT.
  • Dodd sign is a clinical sign that is used to detect the presence of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the leg. It is performed by measuring the circumference of the calf at its widest point and comparing it to the circumference of the unaffected leg. If the circumference of the affected leg is greater than that of the unaffected leg, it may indicate the presence of a DVT.
  • Phelp sign is a clinical sign that is used to detect the presence of a jugular paraganglioma, which is a rare type of tumor that arises from the cells of the paraganglia. It is performed by compressing the ipsilateral common carotid artery for 30 seconds and observing for a rise in blood pressure. A positive Phelp sign is indicated by a rise in blood pressure of more than 10 mmHg.
  • Griesinger sign is a clinical sign that is used to detect the presence of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein, which is a complication of acute otomastoiditis. It is characterized by edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 669

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with sudden-onset sharp chest pain and shortness of breath. He had no history of trauma but reported a recent upper respiratory infection. Physical examination revealed decreased breath sounds on the left side. Chest X-ray and USG thorax done. What images are corresponds with diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In pneumothorax,

  • Radiology plays a crucial role in diagnosis and management.
  • Chest X-ray is often the initial imaging modality. Findings typically include a visible pleural line (image 2), absence of lung markings beyond the line, and potential mediastinal shift. A "deep sulcus sign" may be evident on the affected side
  • The normal lung interface with pleura shows lung sliding with z-lines, which appear as vertical comet tails running down from the pleural surface. In pneumothorax, this sliding is absent and so are the comet tail artifacts from the pleura. The sight of even a single B-line excludes pneumothorax at that location. There is also loss of the lung pulse, the subtle lung oscillation in tandem with cardiac contraction, which is especially important when trying to distinguish between right mainstem intubation (loss of sliding on the left, but lung pulse is present) and a left sided pneumothorax (no sliding or lung pulse).
  • Free intrathoracic air will then reflect incident ultrasound waves, obscuring the visceral pleura beneath; while all dynamic signs will be abolished, A-lines will be seen extending into the far field.
  • On M mode, classical signs for the gray scale imaging are seen:
    • seashore sign: normal lung sliding (image 3)
    • barcode/stratosphere sign: pneumothorax (image 4)

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 230-36

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presents with a history of painful limp. There is no history of drug intake or trauma. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given image?
questions.solution:
• Avascular necrosis (AVN) of the hip, also known as osteonecrosis or ischemic necrosis, is a condition where the blood supply to the femoral head is compromised, leading to bone tissue death. Radiological imaging plays a key role in diagnosing and assessing AVN of the hip. Common imaging modalities include X-rays, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and sometimes computed tomography (CT).
  • X-rays: In the early stages, X-rays may appear normal. As the condition progresses, X-rays may reveal joint space narrowing, sclerosis (increased bone density), and collapse of the femoral head.
  • MRI: MRI is highly sensitive for detecting AVN at an early stage. It can visualize changes in the bone marrow and detect areas of ischemia before they become apparent on X-rays. A classic finding is a crescent sign, representing a subchondral fracture.
  • CT Scan: While less commonly used than X-rays and MRI, CT scans can provide detailed images of the bone structures and are useful for assessing the extent of collapse and deformity.
  • Early detection through imaging is crucial for initiating appropriate interventions such as joint-preserving surgeries
  • Tuberculosis (TB) of the hip, or tuberculous coxitis, is assessed through X-rays and MRI. X-rays reveal joint space narrowing, osteopenia, and periarticular osteoporosis. Subchondral erosions are common. MRI highlights synovial thickening, joint effusion, soft tissue involvement, and bone marrow edema. Early detection is vital for prompt treatment with anti-tubercular medications. Surgery may be necessary for complications

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol II, Page number. 222-224

questions.text: A 35-year-old male working with hammer and chisel had an accident and a foreign body enters the eye. Which of these investigations will be detrimental?
questions.solution:
• In cases of suspected orbital foreign bodies, MRI is generally avoided due to safety concerns related to the presence of metallic objects. Most foreign bodies in the orbit are metallic or contain metallic components, which can be attracted to the strong magnetic fields generated by MRI machines. This can pose a significant risk of injury to the patient and damage to the MRI equipment.
  • Instead, imaging modalities such as computed tomography (CT) are often preferred for assessing orbital foreign bodies. CT scans provide detailed images and can effectively visualize the presence, location, and characteristics of metallic or non-metallic foreign bodies within the orbit without the associated risks of MRI in such cases.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 312-314

choices.text: CT urography can help to confirm the diagnosis
Conservative management focused on relieving obstruction and preventing infections
Surgical correction was considered in persistent cases only

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with recurrent flank pain and urinary tract infections. IVU done shown here. What is not true about the condition?
questions.solution:
• Imaging revealed a retrocaval ureter, a congenital anomaly where the right ureter passes behind the inferior vena cava, causing obstruction. CT urography can help to confirm the diagnosis, depicting the characteristic "reverse J" or "fishhook" appearance of the ureter.
  • Conservative management focused on relieving obstruction and preventing infections. Surgical correction was considered in persistent cases. This case highlights the importance of imaging in diagnosing anatomical abnormalities leading to urinary tract symptoms, guiding appropriate management decisions for symptomatic relief and prevention of complications.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 895

choices.text: Well-defined, eccentrically located lytic lesion reaching upto epiphysis of distal radius, characteristic of a aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC).
Core needle biopsy confirmed the diagnosis.
The patient needs to underwent surgical resection,
The defect is reconstructed with bone grafting.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with a gradually enlarging mass on her left wrist. X-ray done shown below. What is not true about the condition?
questions.solution:
Giant cell tumours (GCTs) of the wrist

  • typically, present as lytic lesions, commonly affecting the distal radius. Radiological imaging, such as X-rays and MRI, aids in diagnosis and treatment planning:

X-rays:

Location: Eccentrically located in the epiphysis or metaphysis of the distal radius.

Margins: Well-defined borders with cortical thinning and expansion.

Matrix: Typically, soap bubble or honeycomb appearance due to cystic spaces within the tumour.

Soft Tissue Involvement: X-rays help assess involvement of adjacent soft tissues.

Core needle biopsy confirmed the diagnosis. The patient underwent surgical resection, and the defect was reconstructed with bone grafting. Regular follow-ups and imaging monitored for recurrence. GCTs of the wrist, though typically benign, may be locally destructive, emphasizing the importance of accurate diagnosis, prompt intervention, and close postoperative surveillance to ensure optimal management and functional outcomes.

Giant cell tumors (GCT) and aneurysmal bone cysts (ABC) are bone lesions that can be differentiated based on certain X-ray findings:

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT):

Location: Typically occurs in the epiphysis of long bones, frequently seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and distal radius.

Margins: Well-defined, but the border may become indistinct as the tumor grows.

Matrix: Characteristic soap-bubble or honeycomb appearance due to numerous small cystic spaces within the lesion.

Soft Tissue Involvement: GCTs can extend to the adjacent soft tissues.

Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC):

Location: Often found in the metaphysis of long bones.

Margins: Typically well-defined, with a thin, expanded cortex.

Matrix: Fluid-filled cavities separated by fibrous septa, giving it a "blown-out" appearance.

Soft Tissue Involvement: Less commonly extends into the soft tissues compared to GCT.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol II, Page number. 1616-161

choices.text: Primarily affects male infants, involving abnormal folds of tissue within the urethra, leading to urinary tract obstruction
Postnatally, infants may present with a palpable abdominal mass, poor urinary stream, and signs of renal impairment.
Surgical intervention is the mainstay of treatment, involving the transurethral ablation or resection of the obstructing valves.
Antenatally, mother should be given folic acid tablets to prevent the complications

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman underwent a routine antenatal ultrasound at 20 weeks. The scan revealed bilateral hydronephrosis and a dilated, fetal bladder wall was thickened, and amniotic fluid index was elevated (polyhydramnios). Bladder images given below. What is true about diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given image shows, characteristic key hole appearance seen in Posterior Urethral Valves (PUV) , a congenital condition that primarily affects male infants, involving abnormal folds of tissue within the urethra, leading to urinary tract obstruction. The urethral valves, located in the posterior urethra, cause impedance of urine flow from the bladder. PUV is a significant cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in newborns.

Key features of PUV include:

  • Hydronephrosis: Obstruction leads to the backup of urine into the kidneys, causing dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces (hydronephrosis).
  • Dilated Bladder: The bladder becomes distended and hypertrophied due to increased pressure from the obstruction. (Key hole appearance )
  • Thickened Bladder Wall: Chronic obstruction results in thickening of the bladder wall.
  • Impaired Renal Function: Prolonged obstruction can lead to damage and dysfunction of the kidneys.

Clinical Presentation:

Prenatally, PUV may be suspected based on antenatal ultrasound findings such as bilateral hydronephrosis.

Postnatally, infants may present with a palpable abdominal mass, poor urinary stream, and signs of renal impairment.

Management:

Antenatal: Early detection through routine antenatal ultrasound allows for appropriate planning and counseling.

Postnatal: Surgical intervention is the mainstay of treatment, involving the transurethral ablation or resection of the obstructing valves. Long-term follow-up is necessary to monitor renal function and urinary tract health.

PUV is a potentially serious condition requiring prompt diagnosis and intervention to prevent renal damage and associated complications. Early detection, often through antenatal screening, enables timely postnatal management and improves outcomes for affected infants.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 901-90

questions.text: SPECT Stands for
questions.solution:
• SPECT Stands for Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography, it uses a 360 degree revolving Gamma Camera and Acquires 3D images using tc99m labelled radioisotopes like HMPAO
  • Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography, commonly known as SPECT, is a nuclear medicine imaging technique that provides three-dimensional images of functional processes within the body. SPECT is particularly useful for studying blood flow, assessing organ function, and detecting abnormalities or diseases.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 96

questions.text: Identify the type of bleed shown
questions.solution:
Subdural hematoma (SDH) and epidural hematoma (EDH) are two types of traumatic brain injuries that involve the accumulation of blood within the intracranial space. While both can result from head injuries, they have distinct characteristics, and their management approaches differ.

Subdural Hematoma (SDH):

Pathophysiology: SDH occurs when blood collects between the dura mater (the outermost layer of the brain covering) and the arachnoid mater (the middle layer). It is often a result of tearing veins that bridge the subdural space.

Clinical Presentation: Symptoms may include headache, confusion, drowsiness, and neurological deficits. The onset of symptoms can be gradual.

Imaging: Concavo-convex shape- Diagnosis is typically made through imaging studies, such as CT (computed tomography) or MRI (magnetic resonance imaging).

Management:

Observation: Small, asymptomatic SDHs may be managed conservatively with close observation.

Evacuation: Larger or symptomatic SDHs may require surgical evacuation. Burr hole drainage or craniotomy may be performed.

 

Epidural Hematoma (EDH):

Pathophysiology:

EDH occurs when blood collects between the dura mater and the skull, often as a result of arterial bleeding, commonly from the middle meningeal artery.

Clinical Presentation:

EDH often presents with a brief loss of consciousness followed by a lucid interval and then a rapid deterioration of neurological status. It is associated with a more acute onset of symptoms.

Imaging: Crescent shaped- Diagnosis is usually made through imaging studies, especially CT scans.

Management:

Emergent Surgical Intervention: EDH typically requires immediate surgical evacuation. This involves a craniotomy to remove the blood clot and control bleeding.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 291-296

questions.text: A 2-year-old male presented with developmental delays and deteriorating motor skills. MRI Brain with spectroscopy analysis of the child is shown, what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Canavan disease

  • A rare genetic disorder that primarily affects the central nervous system. It is characterized by the absence or malfunction of an enzyme called aspartoacylase, leading to the accumulation of N-acetylaspartic acid (NAA) in the brain. This accumulation results in progressive damage to the white matter of the brain. Radiological findings in Canavan disease are often evident on imaging studies such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Here are the typical radiological findings associated with Canavan disease:

White Matter Abnormalities: MRI of the brain typically reveals abnormal signal intensity in the white matter, especially in the cerebral hemispheres. This abnormal signal is often hyperintense on T2-weighted images and hypointense on T1-weighted images.

Lack of Myelin: Canavan disease is characterized by a lack of myelin, the protective covering of nerve fibers. This lack of myelin is often seen as increased signal intensity on T2-weighted images in areas where myelin should normally be present.

Globular Appearance: The white matter abnormalities can give a globular or spongy appearance on imaging, which is characteristic of Canavan disease.

Frontal Lobe Predominance: The abnormalities are often more pronounced in the frontal lobes of the brain. The involvement of the subcortical white matter is a distinguishing feature.

Enlarged Ventricles: As the white matter degenerates, there may be an increase in the size of the lateral ventricles, a phenomenon known as ventriculomegaly.

It's important to note that these radiological findings are not specific to Canavan disease, and other conditions affecting the white matter of the brain may have similar imaging features. A definitive diagnosis of Canavan disease is typically confirmed through genetic testing, which identifies mutations in the ASPA gene responsible for the enzyme deficiency.

A) Alexander disease

  • bifrontal white matter which tends to be symmetrical - caudate head > globus pallidus > thalamus > brainstem

Options B and C-

  • As opposed to main differential diagnosis of metachromatic leukodystrophy, krabbe disease initially shows symmetrical involvement of thalami, caudate nuclei, cerebellum, posterior limb of internal capsule and brainstem which later on extend to centrum semiovale / corona radiata.
  • krabbe
  • mld

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 2120-2121

questions.text:
A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman presented with progressive back pain and height loss over several months. Clinical evaluation revealed tenderness over the lumbar spine, and the patient had experienced no recent trauma. X-ray of spine is shown below. Choose the correct option regarding the condition.

1. MRI Whole spine is to be done to confirm the diagnosis
2. Further laboratory tests to assess calcium, vitamin D, and hormonal levels
3. The patient needs to be initiate on calcium and vitamin D supplementation, along with a bisphosphonate.
4. PET CT demonstrate a significant reduction in bone mineral density (BMD) at the spine.
questions.solution:
• Imaging studies, including dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scan, confirmed a diagnosis of spinal osteoporosis. (<2.5 SD in BMD)
  • Given Xray shows codfish or fish vertebraerefers to the biconcave appearance of vertebrae, especially lumbar vertebrae, seen in several conditions such as osteoporosis, secondary to steroid or heparin therapy, Cushing syndrome, idiopathic, sickle cell disease, leukemia, Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
  • The biconcave deformity of the vertebral body is more common than anterior vertebral wedging and flat vertebra signs.It is not pathognomonic of postmenopausal osteoporosis and can be seen in other conditions and secondary causes of osteoporosis .
  • The DXA scan demonstrated a significant reduction in bone mineral density (BMD) at the spine, indicating osteoporosis. (<2.5 SD in BMD)
  • Further investigations included laboratory tests to assess calcium, vitamin D, and hormonal levels. The results revealed low vitamin D levels and elevated parathyroid hormone, contributing to secondary osteoporosis.
  • The patient to be initiated on calcium and vitamin D supplementation, along with a bisphosphonate to improve bone density and reduce the risk of fractures. - osteoporotic collapse. Physical therapy is recommended for strengthening exercises and postural improvement.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 2692

questions.text: Which of the following views is used for visualizing apices of the lung?
questions.solution:
When it comes to visualizing the apices of the lungs, the lordotic view takes precedence. This radiographic view is specifically designed to capture clear images of the lung apices and the middle lobe. By employing the lordotic view, radiologists can enhance their ability to detect and diagnose conditions affecting these areas, contributing to more accurate assessments of lung health.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive Textbook of Diagnostic Radiology, 2nd Edition, Page no 1144

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication of Paget's disease of bone?
questions.solution:
Osteoarthritis.

This complication arises due to the abnormal bone architecture leading to joint stress and secondary degenerative changes. Pathological fractures and high-output cardiac failure are also complications but are less common than osteoarthritis. Osteogenic sarcoma occurs in a small percentage of cases, while hypercalcemia of malignancy is not directly associated with Paget's disease.

  • Paget's disease of bone is characterized by the disorganized bone remodeling process, leading to bones that are larger, weaker, and more prone to fractures. The etiology is not fully understood, but there is a genetic component and environmental factors such as paramyxovirus infection have been implicated. Clinically, patients may be asymptomatic or present with bone pain, deformities, and complications like osteoarthritis and hearing loss due to nerve compression.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol II, Page number. 1524-1525

choices.text: Acute flaccid paralysis possibly due to poliomyelitis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with a gradual onset of weakness and atrophy in his right hand. Neurological examination revealed asymmetrical muscle wasting and weakness in the C7 to T1 myotomes, along with cold intolerance. Electromyography (EMG) confirmed denervation changes in the affected muscles. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine demonstrated forward displacement of the posterior dural sac during neck flexion. Above findings are in favour to?
questions.solution:
Hirayama disease, also known as monomelic amyotrophy (MMA),

  • is a rare, self-limiting neurological disorder that predominantly affects young males. The disease is characterized by progressive weakness and atrophy of the distal muscles of upper limb, often the hand and forearm, without sensory loss.

The pathophysiology

is believed to involve forward displacement of the posterior dural sac and compression of the cervical spinal cord during neck flexion, leading to ischemic damage to the anterior horn cells.

Diagnostic Imaging:

MRI of the cervical spine is the key diagnostic modality. In the neutral position, MRI may appear normal, but in flexion, it typically shows an asymmetrically narrowed cervical spinal canal with forward displacement of the posterior dural sac and flattening of the lower cervical cord. This anterior shift is more pronounced during neck flexion and is often accompanied by an enhancing epidural crescent sign, indicative of venous congestion.

Clinical Management:

 Treatment primarily involves avoidance of neck flexion and the use of a cervical collar to prevent further progression. Physiotherapy may help maintain muscle strength and function. The disease course is usually self-limiting, with a stabilization phase after a progressive period. Regular follow-up is essential to monitor for disease progression or complications.

 

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol II, Page number. 2098-2100

choices.text: X-ray given suggests changes related to Bronchopneumonia
Additional involvement of liver, spleen, and bone marrow can occur
Sputum microscopy and GeneXpert testing is to be done to confirm the diagnosis
None of the statements are correct

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented with a month-long history of persistent fever, night sweats, and weight loss. Chest X-ray shows below. What is not true about the condition?
questions.solution:
Chest X-ray reveals diffuse, small nodular opacities throughout both lung fields.
Xray finding with clinical findings of fever, cough and weight loss, first differential to be consider is miliary tuberculosis (TB).

Further investigations, including sputum microscopy and GeneXpert testing, confirmed Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.

Prior history of TB and Immunocompromised states, such as HIV infection, should be ruled out.

Computed Tomography (CT) scan demonstrated widespread miliary nodules in the lungs and additional involvement of liver, spleen, and bone marrow.

Initiation of anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) is promptly initiated. Corticosteroids were added to mitigate inflammation and prevent paradoxical reactions. The patient shows a gradual clinical improvement with resolution of symptoms and radiological findings during the course of treatment.

Miliary tuberculosis results from hematogenous dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, leading to widespread organ involvement

A miliary pattern on imaging refers to the appearance of numerous small, widely distributed nodules resembling millet seeds. Various conditions can manifest with a miliary pattern, and causes include:

Tuberculosis (TB): Miliary TB occurs when Mycobacterium tuberculosis disseminates through the bloodstream, affecting multiple organs, particularly the lungs. It presents as widespread tiny nodules on imaging.

Fungal Infections: Certain fungal infections, such as Histoplasmosis and Coccidioidomycosis, can lead to a miliary pattern in the lungs when the fungi disseminate hematogenously.

Miliary Metastases: Certain cancers, especially haematological malignancies (leukaemia and lymphoma), can spread to distant organs, causing a miliary pattern.

 

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page number. 566

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male presented with complained backpain and increased frequency of urination, urgency, nocturia, and a weak urinary stream. The patient denied any haematuria, fever, or recent urinary tract infections. Digital rectal examination revealed an enlarged, non-tender prostate. Which of the following is true about the condition?

a. Next line of investigation includes S. PSA level, mpMRI, Uroflowmetry.
b. Next line of investigation includes Leukemia workup
c. Differentials to be considered are Ca. Lung, RCC and melanoma
questions.solution:
Given image suggest Ivory vertebrae, also known as dense or sclerotic vertebrae, refer to a radiological appearance where the vertebral body appears abnormally dense on imaging studies such as X-rays. Several medical conditions can lead to the development of ivory vertebrae:

Etiology

  • The cause for an ivory vertebra depends on the age of the patient.

Paediatric

lymphoma: commonest cause, usually Hodgkin lymphoma

osteosarcoma

osteoblastoma

blastic metastatic disease

neuroblastoma

medulloblastoma

Ewing sarcoma (rare)

Adult

osteoblastic metastases- prostate cancer and breast cancer

lymphoma (usually Hodgkin lymphoma)

tuberculous spondylitis

hemangioma

chordoma

Paget disease of bone

Vertebral body expansion (unlike hemangioma)

coarsened trabeculae

SAPHO syndrome

Rarely, the ivory vertebra can also be seen in:

primary bone sarcoma

sarcoidosis

systemic mastocytosis

A helpful mnemonic is LIMPH.

Here elderly patient having lower back pain with xray suggestive of ivory vertebrae and LUTS (lower urinary tract symptoms) with enlarged non tender prostate are in favour of suspected prostate maliganancy.

  • Initial evaluation includes a thorough medical history, International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) questionnaire, and basic laboratory tests. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels.
  • A uroflowmetry test shows a decreased peak urinary flow rate.
  • Further investigations, such as MpMRI, ( Multiparametric Magnetic Resonance Imaging), combines various sequences like T1-weighted, T2-weighted, Diffusion-Weighted, and Dynamic Contrast-Enhanced Imaging for detailed tissue evaluation. Widely used in prostate cancer diagnosis, it provides high-resolution images and enhances accuracy in detecting and characterizing lesions.
  • Its applications extend to assessing multiple organs, aiding in tumor detection and staging. Though limited by cost and expertise requirements, mpMRI remains a valuable tool in modern diagnostic radiology.

Furthur investigation includes transrectal ultrasound or cystoscopy, may be considered for a definitive diagnosis.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol II, Page number. 552
